strapiArticle.title: Sinigang
strapiArticle.description: Sinigang is a Filipino soup or stew .

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Ingredients:

  • 500 grams of pork ribs or pork belly, cut into serving pieces
  • 1 medium-sized onion, peeled and quartered
  • 2 medium-sized tomatoes, quartered
  • 1 bundle of kangkong (water spinach), leaves and tender stems separated
  • 1 medium-sized daikon radish (labanos), peeled and sliced
  • 1 medium-sized eggplant, sliced
  • 1 medium-sized taro root (gabi), peeled and sliced (optional)
  • 8-10 pieces of okra, ends trimmed
  • 2 tablespoons of tamarind paste or 3-4 pieces of tamarind sinigang mix packets
  • Fish sauce (patis) or salt, to taste
  • Water
  • Cooking oil

Instructions:

  1. In a large pot, heat a little oil over medium heat. Saut√© the onions until translucent and fragrant.

  2. Add the pork ribs or pork belly to the pot and cook until browned on all sides.

  3. Pour enough water into the pot to cover the meat. Bring it to a boil, then lower the heat to simmer. Let it cook for about 1 to 1.5 hours until the meat is tender. You may need to skim off any impurities that rise to the surface.

  4. Once the meat is tender, add the tomatoes to the pot and let them simmer for a few minutes until they soften and release their juices.

  5. Stir in the tamarind paste or tamarind sinigang mix packets. If using tamarind paste, dissolve it in a little water before adding it to the pot.

  6. Add the daikon radish and taro root (if using) and simmer for about 5 minutes until they start to soften.

  7. Add the eggplant, okra, and kangkong stems to the pot and let them cook for a few minutes.

  8. Finally, add the kangkong leaves and season the soup with fish sauce or salt according to your taste preference. Simmer for another 2-3 minutes until the vegetables are cooked but still slightly crisp.

  9. Serve the Sinigang hot with steamed rice. You can also serve it with fish sauce or patis on the side for dipping.

Enjoy the comforting and tangy flavors of Sinigang!
